title: AMA Legacy Esports! 6-7PM AEST!
body:
Helloooo Gamers!!

We're **Legacy Esports** and we are doing an AMA from **6-7PM AEST**.
Shoot us any question at any player and we will answer it tonight.

**Tally ** (Top Laner) - [Twitter](https://twitter.com/Tallywhacka) / [Twitch](https://www.twitch.tv/tallywhacka)

**Carbon** (Jungler) - [Twitter](https://twitter.com/OCECarbon) / [Twitch](https://www.twitch.tv/carb0n2)

**Claire** (Mid Laner) - [Twitter](https://twitter.com/ClaireOCE) / [Twitch](https://www.twitch.tv/c14ir3)

**Lost** (AD Carry) - [Twitter](https://twitter.com/Lost_adc) 

**Cupcake** (Support) - [Twitter](https://twitter.com/cupcakeoce) / [Twitch](https://www.twitch.tv/cupcakeoce)

**SoulStrikes** (Coach) - [Twitter](https://twitter.com/SoulStrikesOCE)

**Babip** (Sub) - [Twitter](https://twitter.com/BabipOCE)

Join the Legacy family tree!
[Official Website](https://legacyesports.com.au/) / [Twitter](https://twitter.com/LegacyOCE) / [Facebook](https://www.facebook.com/LegacyOCE)

Thanks guys!
**ASK AWAY!!!!**

http://i.imgur.com/V1YK835.jpg[/img]

replies.body:
For Tally: What was the hardest part about transitioning to a different role on competitive League of Legends?

For Cupcake and Lost: When you guys first started playing competitively together did everything just click into place or was there a lot of behind the scenes practice before you started to be on the same page as eachother?

For Claire: Not a question but your Viktor play in game 1 and 2 of OPL Split 1 2017 Week 6 verse the Chiefs is one of my favorite OPL performances to date!

I think we kinda had a slow start, mostly due to the fact that neither of us had played on a top team before; so we had a lot to learn. But eventually we grew trust between each other and things kinda just fell into place :^)
Hey Blaykey, thanks a lot! You might even see more Viktor tomorrow against them ;)

I'd say the hardest thing about role swapping was re learning the game from another perspective. It took me 3 years to reach a point on ADC where I knew the matchups in and out and was confident playing any champions that were strong in the meta. I've been playing Top lane for just over a year now and they're still times where I'm learning matchups and not sure what the best pick is in the situation I'm put in.

**@Babip**: What's life like as a sub in the Legacy gaming house and working with two Junglers, coach and player?

**@Lost**: Pretend Cupcake _totally_ can't read this and tell me when I can come and play for the roster, I'm a mean Trundle.
Actual question for you though, what's the one thing **you** believe it takes to be a #1 team in a region?

Best of luck tomorrow!

Hey Rusty, living in the gaming house as a sub has been a really great experience and has allowed me to accelerate my learning and development as a player through working with the main team and being able to sit in on Vod review and whilst they scrim. Actively collaborating and sharing information with Tim 'Carbon' on a day to day basis is an opportunity i am very grateful for and hope to prove myself in the near future.

hahahahaha our winrate as a bot lane is insane man :'), gimme more of that freelo. I think the team that works with the most diligence throughout the split is the one that has the best shot at winning; not the team that works the most hours. But i haven't won a single final in OPL yet so who am i to say anything about winning the whole league right? (T_T)

Team; Do you have enough time in your schedule for other non league things, like relationships?

Anyone; I won a LGC prizepack a while back, and amongst some of the awesome swag.... [was this thing](https://gyazo.com/9fb3a7ee2caccf9555d2e29210e8db3d). I don't know what it is, and none of my friends know. What is it?
If you peel the back off you can stick it on your phone and put your Opal card or something in there.
I'm currently doing long distance but we only have 1 day off, otherwise we are practising all day every day.

Nah there's virtually no time to build relationships or have hobbies outside of the house. You have time for the basic necessities of everyday life and things you can start and drop really quick while you're at your computer, but that's it.

It's a cardholder you put on the back of your phone :)
@everyone are you guys any good?
If winning OPL this split means you're good, then yeah. We're gonna be good.
this is if for the team really what has been the best experience to date within the whole Esports career and what do you normally do before a game to get into the zone before you play a game?

Rift rivals was probably the best experience i've had to date. Riot did a really good job of taking care of the players; and being able to play against international teams in a country that i've never been to is a memory to cherish. I don't really have anything to get me into the zone, i just avoid thinking of anything that has no relevance to league.

I would say as a team, us 2-0'ing the Chiefs in Split 1 was a great feeling for all of us, and we were also at the top of the table so it felt like nothing could go wrong :P hopefully we'll have a more impressive highlight by the end of this year!

My best experience so far was probably playing in front of the crowd at Luna Park in 2015 for the OPL Grand Finals. The crowd was amazing and probably the biggest I've ever played for. I definitely miss LANs in OCE. 

Meditation helps but other than that nothing really, I'm usually just daydreaming haha..

The most fun I've had at an event was probably All-Stars in Melbourne 2015. It was in my hometown and I got to play with Chuz Raydere and Egym (and Ryoo) who were friends of mine. I also did pretty well in the 1v1s and heard about 2-3000 people chant my name so that was a surreal experience. 

To get into the zone I usually like to do some light exercise (star jumps or pushups) just to get the blood flowing. If i'm not feeling that though I like to meditate.

Question for Soulstrikes: When do we get to see Babip subbing in on the main stage?? {{summoner:14}} 

Question for all - how did you guys find the Vietnam Rift Rivals experience and what was the best food you ate over there?

Rift Rivals was super fun, definitely a more lighthearted event though. I'm still hungry for a real competitive experience.

It's way too hard to make a call on what the best food was.. eating local food at pretty much every restaurant was great!

Personally I didn't enjoy Vietnamese food at all :P we were taken care of very well at the Hotel, but I much prefer Korean or Western food. The tournament itself helped us get a better idea of the strenghts and weaknesses of our team, and for me, re-ignited the competitive drive that can dwindle on the OCE scene.

**Carbon** - how different is it being in a pro team now compared to when you first started? Obviously the gaming houses make a massive difference, but in terms of how your week works, what you do outside of playing League and just in general, is it a whole different world?

**Tally** - your Master Yi from last season is probably still my favorite pick I've seen in the OPL. Any more borderline troll picks up your sleeve?

**Claire** - Assassins or Mages? And why?

**Lost & Cupcake** - why do you two seem to work so well together? Or I guess a better question is what do you think makes for good duo lane synergy?

**Babip** - pretend the rest of the team didn't see this. If you could take one of their places, who would you boot out?

**Soulstrikes** - what's your post-match ritual? Do you have certain standards in place for how long you wait til after the game to review it?  And what do you think is more important to get right - your picks or your bans?


#LGCWIN

Completely different, I used to play qualifiers for tournaments from the lounge room in my parents house. They used to listen to me shotcall on a thursday night while they watched the voice lmao. Nowadays it's training for most of the day everyday and me trying to fit in gym/analyst desk/lgc work wherever I can.
@brandon Can I get a tier graph of mid lane champions? <3

This is a tough one.. mid has no 'best' champions atm. There's a lot of counter matchups and comfort picks involved. I think the popular stable picks atm are Orianna, Kassadin, Corki, Ahri, Syndra, Taliyah, Cassiopeia. Ahri and Syndra are good champs to pick if you're confident, they don't really have counters.
Ahri no counters :D
What is LGC Lawrence Lost's secret to get girls and be good at the game at the same time ;))
Cmon bruh i get so few girls i could probably pass for a homo
Tits or Ass?

Do you guys watch other regions to pick up strategy and experience as part of your training? What do you think of the recent slump of form from  SKT and do you think they will bounce back or are other teams in the region got their measure now?

Would an OPL team be in the market to import a retired player such as Krepo or Crumbs or Darius into the league from oversea to gain experience from, or would that be way out of budget?

And if you could import a player to the region who would you most like that player to be?

I think that'd be interesting but I'd imagine that the ratio of budget to knowledge gained would be fairly bad..

Probably a top tier English speaking jungler.. not sure who though.

Hey Legacy!

**Lost:** What are your thoughts on the recent leathality changes as an ADC main and how does this effect you?

---

**Tally:** When can we expect the return of your Riven? :P

---

**Anyone who is keen to answer:** Now that you have had a decent amount of time having the region being in gaming houses how do you think it has effected the scene and what do you think the next big step for the scene is in this sort of area?

---

Thankyou!

I can see myself getting three shot every single time i walk anywhere on the map that isn't my fountain; so im not too psyched for the lethality changes really. But hey, jhin and varus can still build the lethality items so if you can't beat em join em right :D

I think every team has improved and we're starting to see more parity but a lot of what drives the scene atm is just pure motivation and passion. eSports in Australia is not yet lucrative and we don't have a big fan/viewerbase but we're building towards it!

Well since I only entered the competitive scene this year which is the first year of having gaming houses, it's hard to compare personally with the previous years. But I do think it has helped the scene's overall level grow and the gap between teams to shrink.
@claire can you say something cute/gay about "Miracle" hes a guy from serbia that's a huge fan of you
Hey Miracle, I love you! <3

For everyone or anyone:
1. What is the best way to be playing your role? (for example, for jungle, what would be the best jungle path)

2. Any up coming events that may happen that we will be able to see you guys at, like conventions?

3. What are your thoughts on Kayn and will we be seeing him in pro play when he becomes available?

That's all, keep up the great work and good luck in future

-Emyrald :)

I don't think there is a 'best' way to play mid lane.. I think the 'best' outcome depends on the champion you're playing. Sometimes you just want to get a cs lead and scale while denying as much cs as possible and sometimes you want to roam a lot and sacrifice your own lane. It really depends on the champion.

We have no plans for any conventions or anything but generally if I'm free and something fun is on that I know a lot of people are going to I'll probably go.

Kayn seems pretty decent, no idea yet.

Kind of a broad question. There isn't really one best jungle path but I will say that doing Raptors will give you the most XP lvl1 so you should always try to start there if possible.

We don't have plans to attend any conventions at the moment though we have been at PAX Aus the last couple of years.

I think they're looking at buffing Kayn so I'm not sure whether we will see him before that. He's definitely a lot of fun but I'm not sure how viable he is.

For the whole team.

What age did you get into the competitive scene?
I think i was 13 years old when i first entered competitive,with a new zealand team
I played what was considered OCE competitive back in season 2.. so it's been a long time. I was 14 at the time.
I got into the competitive scene at the start of this year, when I was 22
I was 21 when I played my first online tournament in late 2013.

I got into competitive league a month after I turned 17. At the time I was pretty much doing nothing, I dropped out of highschool and decided I really wanted to pursue something I enjoyed for once. My first ever LAN was Armageddon NZ in 2014, just playing in front of a crowd doing something I really enjoyed was enough to keep me hooked all this time.
@Everyone, how long does it take you to learn a new champion well enough to use them competitively in the OPL?

Yeah this one is a weird one to answer because some champions just click and others I can not for the life of me play well on. Mid Lane hasn't really gotten a lot of new champions though so I'm pretty lucky :p

If I have seen the champion being played a lot, it takes less time for me to master that champion myself. If it's a brand new champion, I would want to spam it in solo queue for a week and give it a try in some scrims before I'd want to pull it out in OPL :)
